title: Broad Ripple businesses hopeful New Year's Eve celebrations lead to a prosperous 2024 - WRTV Indianapolis
content:
INDIANAPOLIS — The Broad Ripple neighborhood experienced a brutal 2023, with several shootings and lingering construction on its main street. Business owners there hope 2024 brings better days for the entertainment district.

"We're ready for you to come back," said Patrick Sparks, who has owned Brick House Piano Bar for nearly a decade. "Come back to us. We need your support and we need your business."

Broad Ripple bars will likely see a lot of their customers come back for New Year's Eve celebrations Sunday night.

"There's a lot of different kinds of bars here, so it's fun," said Chris Good, who visited Kilroy's Bar & Grill in Broad Ripple on Friday night. "I think I will be here for New Year's Eve."

Sparks said the business is needed more than ever. He claims Brick House lost $200,000 in 2023 due to both construction on Broad Ripple Avenue and violence in the district.

The tipping point came in June, when three people died in a shooting during the early morning hours.

He said business owners are working together to make the neighborhood safer going into 2024, including employing off-duty cops on busy weekend nights.

"We're working really hard," Sparks said. "We meet once a month to get Broad Ripple back to the way it used to be. We like it here."

IMPD has also increased patrols since the deadly shooting in June.

Good considers himself a Broad Ripple regular. He believes visitors should not have to worry about safety.

"If you come out and do your own thing and not get in trouble, you're not going to have trouble," Good said. "You have to go looking for trouble if you're trying to find it. It's pretty simple."

Sparks hopes that trouble stays far away from Broad Ripple in the New Year.

"We'd love to have you back," Sparks said.

title: Cyrusher unveils the world's first electric snowboard ripple - Utah Business - Utah Business
content:
Logan, UT—Cyrusher, a leading brand in e-bikes, has introduced an electrifying marvel to the snowboarding domain: the Ripple, the world’s first electric snowboard. Combining high-tech features with an exhilarating experience, the Ripple redefines winter sports, pushing the boundaries of excitement and performance on snowy slopes to new heights.

Exploring the mystery of the Ripple

Cyrusher Unveils the World’s First Electric Snowboard Ripple

Incorporating advanced technology and meticulous craftsmanship, the Ripple boasts a board size of 156cm, aligning it with the Camber snowboard category. Crafted from composite materials featuring a wood core, fiberglass, and carbon edges, the snowboard’s construction ensures both durability and exceptional riding dynamics. The Ripple is strategically designed to empower a broader range of snowboarders, offering new snowboarding opportunities through innovative electric energy.

Power and Performance

The Ripple stands out as an industry trailblazer, employing cutting-edge electric motors to enhance the snowboarding experience. With a robust 3000-watt motor seamlessly integrated into the snowboard, it delivers heart-pounding top speeds of up to 50 km/h.

The Ripple incorporates an advanced V1 controller specifically designed for accurate navigation across snow and ice-covered landscapes. Equipped with a high-voltage-resistant MOSFET and an advanced heat dissipation, the controller ensures precise control and responsiveness. Easily fine-tune snowboard forward speed and maneuverability for the ultimate snowboarding adventure, guaranteeing a thrilling yet controlled riding experience every time.

The electric power system of the board relies on a low-temperature resistant battery featuring a Molicel 21700 P42A 4200mAh 45A configuration, providing a 12.6 Ah capacity. This innovative battery setup allows the Ripple to cover distances of 15-20 kilometers on a single charge.

Comfort

The Ripple’s board design features a wide, high-traction rear tire, specifically tailored for snowboarding. This design enhances traction on icy snow cover, providing faster snow grip and improved stability on snowy terrain. Skiers can expect maximum stability and control in the snowy domain. Meanwhile, the Ripple introduces an adjustable independent suspension with manual wheel height adjustment, allowing riders to customize their snowboarding adventures by absorbing shocks and seamlessly adapting to the snow’s contours.

Tailored for snowboarding adventures, the Ripple is constructed to withstand various weather conditions. It boasts a full metal enclosure with a flame-retardant design and an impressive IPX6 waterproof rating, ensuring durability and a hassle-free ride in different weather conditions.

Sustainability

The advent of Ripple electric snowboards has revolutionized winter sports, offering sustainable thrills with lithium-ion battery power. The Ripple snowboards are silent and emissions-free, reducing noise pollution and promoting eco-friendly outdoor activities. The development of electric snowboards reflects a promising future for a more sustainable and exciting snowboarding experience.

Multi-Application

The Ripple’s enhanced motor power enables smooth gliding over flat snow, ensuring an exhilarating experience even on the fluffiest terrain. This expands the range and accessibility of the snowboarding terrain, elevating the overall experience. By harnessing electric power, the Ripple enhances the snowboarding adventure, enabling riders to traverse terrain with reduced physical exertion compared to traditional snowboards. The responsive design of the Ripple empowers snowboarders to conquer terrain with unmatched precision and speed, execute tricks and jumps effortlessly, and fully enjoy the sport of snowboarding to its utmost extent.

Experience the Thrill of Snowboarding Like Never Before with the Ripple!

Boasting a maximum load capacity of 250 lbs, and accommodating rider sizes from 160-190cm, the Ripple caters to a wide range of rider needs, ensuring stability and confidence for individuals of all sizes. Weighing in at a total of 15kg, the snowboard is meticulously crafted to strike a balance between portability and performance, offering effortless maneuverability without compromising power.

Infused with cutting-edge technology, robust construction, and unparalleled performance, the Ripple bring a new era in snowboarding. As the world’s first electric snowboard, it grants skiers the freedom to embark on thrilling journeys that redefine the snowboarding experience.

About Cyrusher

Cyrusher is a reputable producer of electric bicycles with a reach into new territories and the exciting introduction of electric snowboards and skateboards to its innovative product lineup. Successfully marketed in over 10 nations, Cyrusher’s products undergo rigorous international quality tests, meeting CE, UL, Rhos, and FCC requirements. With a focus on connecting individuals with nature, Cyrusher invites the customer to explore the thrill of electric mobility. Cyrusher will keep expanding its product range in both land and aquatic areas to satisfy more individuals, offering a solution for zero-carbon, fast and convenient urban traveling.

If you’re interested in Cyrusher products, you can find more information about Cyrusher at the following links.

Cyrusher Contact:

US official website: https://www.cyrusher.com/

UK official website: https://www.cyrusher.co.uk/

French official website: https://www.cyrusher.fr/

German official website: http://www.cyrusher.de/

Phone: (385) 382-1622

Email: [email protected]

Follow Cyrusher on Facebook, TikTok, YouTube and Instagram for more latest news.

SOURCE Cyrusher

title: Nebraska 2024 predictions: Dylan Raiola's ripple effects and non-gridiron guesswork - The Athletic - The New York Times
content:
LINCOLN, Neb. — The biggest moments of the season in the College Football Playoff semifinals are nearly upon us. At Nebraska, it means only that the Cornhuskers are on to next year.

The time has arrived for my annual predictions for the year ahead.

Much of my 2023 forecast held up well. These especially hit the mark:

Dylan Raiola will headline Nebraska’s 2024 recruiting class.

Thomas Fidone and Teddy Prochazka will realize their potential. … More specifically, both will start and avoid serious injuries.

The Blackshirts will get a face-lift. … Tony White is set to bring a new vibe.

But in reviewing what I predicted, much of the material felt obvious or vague. My pledge this year is to be more bold and specific. To help me stay on track, I’m incorporating a few sports other than football to craft this look at the next 12 months.

As always, my picks on the wins and losses next fall will come later.

Advertisement

Here’s to 2024. Let’s get to it.

1. An offensive coaching shift will impact at least two position groups.

Marcus Satterfield isn’t going anywhere as offensive coordinator. But I don’t expect him to coach the quarterbacks next year. Coach Matt Rhule didn’t want to talk about a possible change Dec. 20 as he unveiled the Huskers’ recruiting class.

Rhule’s answer said more than he intended. Something is seemingly in the works. The original plan for 2023 did not involve Satterfield as the QB coach. Rhule will find a solution this year — and likely has identified a candidate who’s still at work in college or in the NFL.

With Raiola and fellow true freshman Daniel Kaelin incoming in a matter of days, there is an urgent need for Nebraska to employ a position coach who’s dedicated to their growth. An easy place to look is at Glenn Thomas, the Pittsburgh Steelers assistant who coached quarterbacks and helped coordinate the offense with Rhule at Temple and Baylor. Offensive analyst Adam DiMichele factors in the equation, too.

But because of the attractiveness of the job, Rhule can search outside his immediate coaching circle, as he did last year in finding Tony White, a home run hire.

2. The Huskers will add a quarterback, running back and wide receiver to their group of newcomers by the summer.

Chubba Purdy is gone, leaving Nebraska with one returning QB on scholarship in Heinrich Haarberg. Haarberg is the consummate teammate. But he’s not what the Huskers want as a primary option at quarterback, despite his five wins in eight starts this year as a sophomore.

Otherwise, the roster includes three walk-ons and the two incoming true freshmen. Lack of depth and experience is a concern. The Huskers ought to scour the transfer portal for a veteran who fits the Rhule mold and won’t balk at handing the spotlight to Raiola if the freshman is ready.

Advertisement

The Huskers have young options aplenty at receiver, but they need a leader for the position group and natural WR1. And at running back, Nebraska is one misstep away from facing a big bind in the spring as Gabe Ervin and Rahmir Johnson recover from injuries. Dante Dowdell, in the portal from Oregon and scheduled to visit Lincoln in January, deserves Nebraska’s top recruiting effort.

3. Nebraska basketball will make the NCAA Tournament.

Fred Hoiberg’s fifth team is off to a 10-2 start, equaling Nebraska’s best 12-game opening stretch since 1994-95. With a win Friday night at home against South Carolina State, the Huskers will close nonconference play with one loss for the fifth time since World War II.

Nebraska boasts nice wins against Michigan State and at Kansas State. But a 29-point loss in Lincoln against Creighton and a second-half collapse at Minnesota tempered some of the early excitement.

The Huskers have made one NCAA appearance in the past 25 seasons. With a NET ranking of 57, this is doable. The Big Ten appears manageable for Nebraska to finish at .500 or better in league play, which should be enough to get in. Early January brings Indiana and Purdue to Pinnacle Bank Arena, sandwiched around a trip to Wisconsin. The Huskers need to get a win in that stretch.

And they need big man Rienk Mast to return from minor knee surgery as soon as possible. He and Juwan Gary, complemented by Josiah Allick, give the Huskers a legit Big Ten frontcourt.

4. Jordy Bahl will contribute to multiple no-hitters and spur record attendance figures for the Nebraska softball team this spring.

OK, I’m not going out on a limb with the second part of that prediction. Since Bahl, the prodigal daughter who won a pair of national championships at Oklahoma, announced her transfer home to Nebraska in June, the Huskers have been exploring options to expand the capacity of Bowlin Stadium.

Advertisement

Season ticket requests skyrocketed. Nebraska is looking to find escape routes from the field for Bahl to avoid a constant crush of postgame attention. She’s going to create waves.

The junior out of Papillion-LaVista is at her best in the big moments. She finished 7-0 with an ERA of 0.18 in the 2023 NCAA postseason. Without the monumental expectations that the Sooners faced, Bahl’s every pitching appearance with the Huskers will feel like a big event. She combined with other pitchers for two no-hitters at Oklahoma and tossed a solo no-no against Iowa in 2022. More are coming.

GO DEEPER 'Oh, my God, it's happening': Why softball champ Jordy Bahl upended it all to come home

5. Raiola will emerge as the clear No. 1 at QB in the spring.

He brings an NFL arm and a rare level of physical preparedness. Outside of Arch Manning, I’m not sure if a QB has entered the college game in recent seasons with the same kind of training as Raiola. He’s worked with several of Dominic Raiola’s QBs from the elder Raiola’s time with the Detroit Lions. Dylan rubbed elbows with the likes of Patrick Mahomes and has trained with the coaches of several former and current NFL quarterbacks.

Rhule said in an interview Dec. 20 that Raiola’s arm talent stacked up well against the college QBs he scouted at numerous pro days as coach of the Carolina Panthers.

Still, the odds are usually stacked against a true freshman to succeed immediately. Look at Manning, who could sit for a second consecutive season at Texas next fall. The difference? Nebraska doesn’t have a player who’s anything like Quinn Ewers ahead of Raiola. His time is coming fast.

GO DEEPER The family forces that guide 2024 top recruit Dylan Raiola

6. Raiola’s presence will provide a shot in the arm for Nebraska in 2025 recruiting.

If Raiola had picked the Huskers in the spring and not spent more than six months committed to Georgia, Nebraska’s recruiting class likely would have looked more like the vision that fans saw in March, when Raiola visited Lincoln with a cast of four- and five-star talents.

In the end, the way it turned out might benefit Rhule. He signed a group of players who want to be at Nebraska. They didn’t pick the Huskers to play alongside Raiola. In building a foundation with two classes that include more than 80 players, Rhule can more easily afford to swing big in the 2025 class. Today in recruiting, more risk than ever comes with the pursuit of elite prospects. Their patience wears thin fast.

Advertisement

Nebraska will win a few battles, notably at the offensive skill spots, early in the 2025 cycle.

7. The Memorial Stadium renovation project will come into focus with plans for even more work outside of the playing venue.

Nebraska athletic director Trev Alberts announced a plan in September to spend $450 million to demolish the south end of Nebraska’s 100-year-old stadium and modernize the whole facility. You think that’s a big project? It is, but I suspect the school would like to do much more.

Work to prepare the stadium for the renovations begins in February. South Stadium and its 22,000 seats will be removed a year from now. Decreased capacity is coming in 2025.

As the university system in 2024 seats a new president, to whom Alberts will report and work alongside on the announced project, expect talk to increase about future phases of construction to build an immersive experience for fans from the time they arrive in the vicinity of Memorial Stadium.

What will Nebraska volleyball do to up the ante in 2024? (Steven Branscombe / Getty Images)

8. Nebraska volleyball will open the season ranked No. 2 and return to the final four.

A bonus prediction: Coach John Cook is going to do something big. He hinted at it this month before Texas blitzed the Huskers in the national championship match.

What could Cook attempt for an encore after Nebraska filled Memorial Stadium four months ago? It might involve a neutral-site match to capitalize on the Huskers’ popularity. Use your imagination. Cook, who turns 68 in April, is using his.

The Longhorns, seeking a third consecutive title, will start at No. 1. The Texas domination of Nebraska (and Wisconsin) in Tampa will fuel the Huskers to improve on their deficiencies with a seasoned group of players — including a big senior class led by Lexi Rodriguez and Merritt Beason in their final opportunity to win a championship.

A tougher-than-ever Big Ten, with the addition of four Pac-12 transfer programs, will sharpen Nebraska on its quest to reach Louisville and get another shot at the big prize.

Advertisement

9. The bowl drought will end.

Simple as that. Nebraska will play in a 13th game for the first time since 2016. It’s a seven-year streak, abhorrent for a program that’s won or shared 46 conference championships, five national championships and played in 54 bowl games. But it’s real.

And it’s the longest drought among power-conference programs nationally. Next behind Nebraska? Vanderbilt, with a five-year postseason absence.

GO DEEPER Nebraska's season ends exactly how it started — a late collapse in a disappointing defeat

10. White will get a head-coaching job.

The 44-year-old defensive coordinator nearly got plucked this year. White re-upped at Nebraska and received a pay raise to $1.6 million. He’s the highest-paid assistant coach in Nebraska history. White deserves the distinction after he rebuilt a defense in his first year that ranked No. 8 nationally in allowing 4.62 yards per play.

The task in 2024 grows more difficult as the Huskers add Ohio State, USC and White’s alma mater, UCLA, to the schedule. But a veteran defense returns that looks like it could rate as Nebraska’s best group since 2010.

Defense again figures to serve as Nebraska’s strength. White’s dynamic personality adds an element to his attractiveness as a head-coaching candidate. Athletic directors will notice.

(Top photo: Dylan Widger / USA Today)
